Classifying and Rewriting Systems of Equations

Find a solution to the system of equations using the addition method.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}x+3y&=&2\\3x+9y&=&6\end{array}\)

Solution

With the addition method, we want to eliminate one of the variables by adding the equations. In this case, let’s focus on eliminating x. If we multiply both sides of the first equation by −3 then we will be able to eliminate the x-variable.

\(x+3y=2\)
\((-3)(x+3y)=(-3)(2)\)
\(-3x-9y=-6\)

Now add the equations.

\(\begin{array}{r}-3x-9y=-6\\+3x+9y=6\\\hline0=0\end{array}\)

We can see that there will be an infinite number of solutions that satisfy both equations.


Try It: Classifying and Rewriting Systems of Equations

Change a single constant term in the system from above so that there are no solutions.

\(x + 3y = 2\)

\(3x + 9y = 6\)

Show that you were successful in changing the system to have no solution.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to rewrite the system so there is no solution:

We can simply change the 2 in the first equation to any other number, such as 5.

\(x + 3y = 5\)

\(3x + 9y = 6\)

Let’s try to prove there is no solution. Using substitution:

\(x + 3y = 5\)

\(x = 5 - 3y\)

Substitute this expression into the second equation.

\(3x + 9y = 6\)

\(3(5 - 3y) + 9y = 6\)

\(15 - 9y + 9y = 6\)

\(15 ≠ 6\)

Since the equation is not true, then the system has no solution.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers. Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!
